Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Symbol server when hosted on prem?" (#8154) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Is there some documentation for enabling the symbols server functionality when hosted on prem? Or is this not possible?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "Display markdown licence files as HTML" (#8151) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This adds support for displaying licence markdown files as HTML. A few notes:

* The `ReadmeService.GetReadMeHtml` should probably be refactored to factor out the MD -> HTML conversion. I have run out of time to do this

* The `CommonMark` library has a weird bug that if a string begins with a BOM, it doesn't convert the first line properly. As a result I stripped it out and then it works ok. It looks like the version of CommonMark used is old, and the package is also depreciated, but I don't have time to fix this either.

* Arguably there could also be another test added for converting licence MD files to HTML, I also haven't done this 

Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7975

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Display markdown licence files as HTML " (#8153) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This adds support for displaying licence MD files as HTML. A few notes:

- I have refactored the `ReadmeService.GetReadMeHtml()` method into it's own service, named MarkdownService. I did this in one commit so that's it's a bit more obvious what's going on. 

- The CommonMark library has a weird bug that if a string begins with a BOM, it doesn't convert the first line properly. As a result I stripped it out and then it works ok. I've added a test for this. (It looks like the version of CommonMark used is old, and the package is also no longer supported, but that's another matter)

- A few of the unit tests eg `PackageControllerFacts.TheDisplayPackageMethod.WhenHasReadMeAndMarkdownExists_ReturnsContent` test that the markdown -> html is working properly, but that's arguably not the concern of the PackageControllerFacts and are tested anyway, inside the MarkdownServiceFacts. However, in the interests of keeping things working I've changed the `PackageControllerFacts` to inject an instantiated `MarkdownService` instead of a Mock. However if someone wiser than me wishes to change it to test against a mock and not test for the MD -> HTML logic then that seems to make sense to me, but it depends on how pure we want the unit tests to be. 

Addresses #7975

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[A11y]Reset button for advanced search filtering does not have sufficient contrast" (#8152) at NuGet/NuGetGallery

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Move GitHub vulnerabilities verifier to its own Job" (#8146) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This continues to address https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7685, as we need the job to authorize using key vault secrets, so we can run it on a PROD VM. Moving it into existing job/config infrastructure achieves this, even though it won't need to be run as an ongoing job (hence Job.RunOnce).

@ryuyu and I discussed this at length as we were trying to get this to connect to the PROD gallery db as a GalleryTools command with a command line connection string authenticating via integrated AAD, but this simply didn't work except on DEV.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Allow `net5.0-platform` projects to be loaded and restored in VS" (#9863) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: NominateProjectAsync API needs to load `TargetFrameworkIdentifier`, `TargetFrameworkVersion`, `TargetFrameworkProfile`, `TargetPlatformIdentifier` and `TargetPlatformVersion` from the property bag, rather than the `TargetFrameworkMoniker` string (which is missing the platform properties, and won't get it).
This is for stuff that definitely needs done by dotnet rc1

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Soulution explorer not showing all nuget package dependencies" (#9898) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/1136736/soulution-explorer-not-showing-all-nuget-package-d.html)._ --- [severity:I'm somewhat annoyed. A fix would be nice] In latest visual studio preview (16.7.0 preview 6.0) then not all nuget package dependencies are show in solution explorer. I have opened the same project in two different Visual Studio instances (other being 16.6.5) and the non preview shows 6 nuget package references but the preview version shows only 4. In the screenshot the preview version is to the left, and non preview to the right. --- ### Original Comments #### Nicolas Fløysvik on 8/5/2020, 02:53 AM:

Just to make it a little clearer, then this is talking about when we navigate to a nuget package under project->dependencies->Packages in the solution explorer and expand a nuget package here to see which other nuget packages it depends on. Then not all nuget packages it depends on are shown.

#### Feedback Bot on 8/5/2020, 11:34 PM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

#### Arturo Ortiz [MSFT] on 8/6/2020, 04:08 PM:

Hi Nicolas,

Thank you for your feedback. We need more information about your solution/projects in order to investigate the issue. Also, if you could please follow these steps to record a repro, that would help us investigate.

Thanks and looking forward to your reply.

#### Nicolas Fløysvik on 8/7/2020, 00:41 AM: I am only able to reproduce it with a private nuget package, but basically I Just install the nuget package in version 16.7 or later and not all the nuget package dependencies are shown. This worked as expected in version 16.6.x of Visual Studio. As can be seen from the nuget package installer then both destructurama.attributed and mediatr are dependencies for this backage, but only IN.x and Serilog are shown here. #### Nicolas Fløysvik on 8/7/2020, 01:06 AM: (private comment, text removed) --- ### Original Solutions (no solutions)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet CLI Bulk Unlister Tool" (#9897) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## **Problem Background**

Within the NuGet CLI, authors can choose either to [unlist](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/nuget-org/policies/deleting-packages#unlisting-a-package) or [deprecate](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/nuget-org/deprecate-packages) particular versions of their published packages to limit public access. There does not currently exist an efficient way to deprecate or unlist multiple or all versions of a package. This presents a process inefficiency that can be potentially significant for customers who must often unlist versions of their package due to security or dependency concerns.  In addition, having to manually unlist package versions can result in human error and lack of thoroughness.

## **Who are the customers**

Specific use cases are:

1. Customers who want to unlist all versions of their published package efficiently.
2. Customers who want to unlist most of the versions, with individual exceptions.
3. Customers who want to unlist a certain range of versions (i.e. 3.x and lower)
4. Customers who want to unlist versions with names that include a particular regular expression pattern. 

## Goals and Success Metrics

**Process Efficiency**

- Provide customers a faster and easier process for unlisting multiple or all versions of a package

**Control**

- Offer customers more control over the unlisting of their package versions.

**Security**

- Drive broader usage of the unlisting functionality to eliminate package vulnerabilities, bugs, and dependency errors across versions

## **Non-Goals**

**[NuGet.org](http://nuget.org) and Visual Studio**

This solution is for the NuGet CLI only. There will be no discussion surrounding UI on [NuGet.org](http://nuget.org) and the Visual Studio version of NuGet

**Deprecation**

This solution is for the unlisting functionality only. There will be no work done on bulk-deprecation.

## **Solution**

The solution will come in a form on a downloadable .NET CLI tool. The first version of this tool will be straightforward and follows the following steps:

1. User invokes "unlist" command 
2. Existing versions are checked against the criteria for unlisting provided by the user
3. List of versions to be unlisted is printed to console. User is prompted to confirm.
    1. If user confirms, the tool proceeds to unlist all versions agreed upon
    2. If user does not confirm, the tool terminates and allows the user to revise their query
4. Once the process is complete, a list of the unlisted files will be printed to console

## **What:**

[Very simplified architecture](https://www.notion.so/Architecture-for-Bulk-Unlister-f7b062984b07440ebade5a0693d6549e) can be found here

[Specific CLI command examples to come]

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "CVE-2020-1340 - NuGet Gallery Spoofing Vulnerability" (#45) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
A spoofing vulnerability exists when the NuGet Gallery does not properly sanitize input on package metadata values. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could perform cross-site scripting attacks and run scripts in the security context of the user viewing the malicious content.

To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker with permissions to upload packages could publish specially crafted content on a gallery page.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how NuGet Gallery sanitizes input.

**MSRC Security Guidance:** [CVE-2020-1340](https://portal.msrc.microsoft.com/en-US/security-guidance/advisory/CVE-2020-1340)
**Security Update:** [v2020.06.09](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/releases/tag/v2020.06.09)
